title: Essex lorry deaths: Fears Vietnamese woman who sent dying texts to mum was on truck
text:

A Vietnamese family have voiced fears their daughter was amongst the 39 victims of the Essex lorry tragedy after she texted them to say she was suffocating.

Pham Thi Tra My, 26, sent a series of frantic messages to her mother at around 10:30 p.m. on Oct. 22, saying that she was "dying because she couldn't breathe".

“I’m sorry Mom, my path to abroad didn’t succeed,” she wrote in one message.

“Mom, I love you and Dad so much! I’m dying because I can’t breathe.”

Her worried family have not heard from her since and have now sought assistance from a human rights activist in their home country.

Have you been affected by this story? Contact us at webnews@trinitymirror.com

(Image: Twitter)

Hoa Nghiem of Human Rights Space in Hanoi wrote about the family's plight on social media and included a picture of the missing woman.

She said: "My's family has asked for help. The person told me there were six other people asking for similar assistance to fund out whereabouts of their relatives or family member since they also lost contact since October 23.

"We don't know if that would make six cases as we are verifying names. And we don't know if they are in that Essex truck. We hope they are not.”

Ms Nghiem said that Ms My had gone to China to begin her journey to the UK in a hope of a better life.

It is believed Ms My unsuccessfully tried to enter the UK in early October but was stopped by police and returned to her point of entry in France.

Her family say she paid people smugglers up to £30,000 in an attempt to gain entry into Britain.

(Image: PA)

Relatives also say she had been making a second attempt to enter Britain before contact with her was cut short.

Two other Vietnamese families have also raised concerns that missing family members may have been onboard the lorry.

They are relatives of a 26-year-old man and a 19-year-old woman.

In a statement, the British embassy in Hanoi said: "The nationality of the victims has not been confirmed at this stage.

"The UK authorities are working as fast as possible to identify the victims and inform their families.

"This is an appalling tragedy and our thoughts and condolences are with the families and friends of all those people who have sadly died.

(Image: PA)

"UK authorities will conduct a full and thorough investigation."

A spokesman for the Vietnamese Embassy said they had been contacted by a family in Vietnam which claimed their daughter had been missing "since the lorry was found".

The spokesman said: "We have contacted Essex Police and we are waiting for an answer."

Police were called to Waterglade Industrial Park in Grays at 1.40am on Wednesday, where they found the bodies of 31 men and eight women.

All of the victims were initially believed to be Chinese nationals, but that has now been called into question.

Sources have claimed preying Snakehead gangs may have been behind the victims' treacherous final journey, where experts say they either suffocated or froze to death.

(Image: Steve Reigate)

Now, police are reportedly probing whether some of the victims were being send to work as prostitutes in the UK, along with slave labour jobs in nail salons, massage parlours and restaurants, reports the Mail.

A 25-year-old Northern Irish man was detained in custody on suspicion of murder on Wednesday after being arrested by the Scania lorry in Grays, Essex.

Meanwhile, police also confirmed a 38-year-old man and a 38-year-old woman from Northern England have been arrested on conspiracy to traffic people and manslaughter.

People living close to Purfleet - the port where the container entered the UK - said illegal migrants were a familiar sight.

"It's a magnet for illegals," said Janet Lilley, 61. "People would come strolling out of the docks, get in the vans and that's it, they drive off."

(Image: PA)

Lee Tubby, 45, who lives opposite the port, said he has seen people "climbing out the top and out the back" of lorries and cutting the plastic roof covering to climb through.

"We've had people just come out of the port knocking on the door asking for shoes, asking for water," he said.

It is not yet known when the victims entered the sealed refrigerated trailer, where temperatures can be as low as -25C, or the exact route it travelled.

Three addresses have been searched in Northern Ireland as part of the probe, while warrants were also carried out in Cheshire.

China has called for joint efforts to counter human smuggling, while vigils have been held in London and Belfast to pay tribute to the victims.
description: Pham Thi Tra My, 26, sent frantic messages to her family on October 22 saying she "couldn't breathe"  - and has not been heard from since
